Description: Establishing the overall goal, target audience, and motivation for the product.
Outlining the major features and strategic goals for the product's evolution over time.
The Product Owner populates the Product Backlog with all known features, requirements, and user stories.
The entire Scrum Team agrees on the criteria that a Product Backlog Item must meet to be considered complete and releasable.
The Scrum Team selects items from the Product Backlog for the upcoming Sprint and creates a plan for how the work will be done.
Result: A Sprint Goal and a Sprint Backlog

Description: The ongoing work by Developers to turn Sprint Backlog items into a valuable, potentially releasable Increment.
A short, 15-minute daily meeting for the Developers to inspect progress toward the Sprint Goal and adapt their plan for the next 24 hours.
Result: A revised daily plan and team synchronization

Description: The ongoing process of adding detail, estimates, and order to items in the Product Backlog. Also known as backlog grooming.
Result: A refined and well-understood Product Backlog

Description: The Scrum Team and stakeholders inspect the Increment from the Sprint. The Product Backlog may be adapted based on feedback.
Result: Stakeholder feedback and an updated Product Backlog

Description: The Scrum Team inspects itself and creates a plan for improvements to its processes, tools, and interactions for the next Sprint.
Result: Actionable improvement items for the next Sprint

Description: The Product Owner decides when to release the Increment(s) to customers. This is a business decision, not a fixed ceremony.
Result: A decision to release and a release plan

Description: Developers frequently merge their code changes into a central repository, after which automated builds and tests are run.
An automated process that reliably builds, tests, and deploys the integrated code to a staging or production environment.
Result: A rapidly deployed new version of the software

Description: Observing the live application for performance/errors and collecting user feedback to inform future development.
Result: New insights, bug reports, and feature ideas for the Product Backlog
